When I‚Äôm out short distance jogging or light training, these are my go to shoes. If I go a little bit longer, I can still feel comfortable because usually what gets to me before I get tired is that the top of my foot can start to feel discomfort from the shoe laces bearing down on them. I also like the shoe laces that come with the shoes. They are also built for comfort and not super rigid.  As for everyone commenting on size, I have used Nike for most of my running career, and have always had to size up in running shoes, as opposed to daily walking around town shoes. I did run in these shoes and I purchased a half size bigger as usual, and they were great. Nike‚Äôs (maybe not all bust most lines) usually run more narrow than most other running shoes. There are a lot of running shoe brands that you should not buy true to size. You really need toe room. I like going to a professional at Fleet Feet to get sized up and try on a bunch of shoes. If they have the shoes I want there, I buy them, if not I can go online and buy a pair‚Ä¶ maybe with a web discount. But this show is super duper comfortable. Next thing I knew I was lying there on the cold, hard sidewalk in such shock I layed there for what felt like forever. I slowly began to rise to my feet. I started to check myself for any injuries when suddenly I got a whiff of a nostril-burning foul smell. I reached my hand around to my back only to bring it right back abruptly.  I let out a loud scream followed by a gagging reaction to the dog poop that was now on my hand.  I ran to the grass and dropped to my knees I frantically began wiping my hand on the grass. I was now lying on the ground once more. As I got to my knees, I stood up quickly, eager to see the culprit that I believed to be the doggy doo doo bandit, but as I turned around to confront this demon, I promptly began to plead because in this dogs mouth was my other shoe I slowly began to approach this dog as I got close enough I made a daring move I tried to jump on the dog. Nike Men's Court Vision Lo Sneaker: Surviving the Mud Monster and Coming Back for More! | If sneakers had a hall of fame for enduring the antics of adventurous teenagers, Nike's Men's Court Vision Lo Sneakers would be first-ballot inductees! I bought a pair for my son last Christmas, and believe me, these shoes have seen things. They've been on a two-year-long expedition into what I can only describe as the 'deep, dark abyss' of mud, rain, and every imaginable teenage adventure.The first pair, affectionately known as 'Mud Divers,' finally succumbed to the relentless exploration. They've been through it all - impromptu soccer games, unexpected puddle jumps, and those mysterious ventures into the woods that only teenagers understand. Yet, they held up with the resilience of a seasoned explorer.So, when Christmas rolled around again, guess what was at the top of my son's list? Another pair of these indomitable Nike Court Vision Lo Sneakers. This time, I'm half expecting them to come with a built-in compass and a survival guide!As for the shoes themselves, they're stylish enough to get approving nods from his fashion-conscious peers and durable enough to withstand his outdoor shenanigans. The comfort level must be through the roof because he wears them like they're part of his feet. I'm beginning to wonder if Nike secretly crafts these with some kind of teenage invincibility technology.If you have a teenager who treats sneakers like they're all-terrain vehicles, Nike's Court Vision Lo Sneakers are the way to go. They're tough, they're trendy, and they might just be the only pair of shoes your teen will ever willingly wear. Here's to hoping the new pair enjoys the same legendary status as the 'Mud Divers'!

He said the tread where his heel is has also begun to wear out but most of the tread is still there. He said he assumes it is because of all the stairs he goes up and down everyday. New Tongueless slip on design comes at the expense of comfort | If you can get your hands on an older style of this shoe, get it.  Reviewers mention that for some reason the newer style is tighter across the big toe bridge or big toe mound and it is. That is because in order to accommodate the tongueless slip on style, the lace-up area had to extend at least an inch more toward the toe end of the shoe.  This means all the stitching relative to the top of the lace-up mock tongue lies straight on top of your big toe knuckle, generally the widest part of most people's foot. The shoe on the right is an old worn style size 8.5 and very comfortable.  I tried women's size 9 and 9.5 of the new style and gotten no relief. However, I love the feel of the old style of these shoes.  I resolved the issue by going with a man's size 7.5 pictured on the left.  The men's shoe is too big is some ways, but not painful across the top of the metatarsal. The men's color choices are less appealing as well. Unless you have a very narrow foot, I would not recommend these shoes.  The design change is not a plus.  I'm going to hang on to the old ones until the y fall completely apart.

Not as nice or comfy as I remember Nike Free Running Shoes to Be | I bought these because they had the "old" or first generation Nike Free tread pattern. The one with deep horizontal and vertical sipes or cuts in the thread to allow for maximum flexibility.The new or 2nd gen tread pattern is hexagonal and not nearly as flexible.So I expected these shoes to feel like older models of Nike Free shoes, which were incredibly comfortable. Both for being light and flexible and having just the right of cushioning for running on the pavement but still feeling more "free" and barefoot-ish than regular shoes.Unfortunately, these shoes come without a tongue and that makes them too tight on the foot for real comfort. You can't adjust the tightness and so they push down on the top of your foot which hurts after a while.The shoes also aren't as light as they really should be or used to be. This might be because Nike tried to make them more durable with reinforcements, but I don't buy Nike Free Running shoes for durability. I buy them for comfort.
